statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Boston College 59, Clemson 54
article.story: BOSTON (AP) -- Jared Dudley had 23 points and 11 rebounds, and Sean Marshall scored 18 on Saturday to help Boston College beat Clemson 59-54 and snap a three-game losing streak that knocked the Eagles from first place in the Atlantic Coast Conference. Dudley, Marshall and Tyrese Rice, who scored 14, accounted for all but four of Boston College's points. BC (19-9, 10-5 ACC) had lost to Duke, North Carolina and Virginia Tech in an eight-day span to put their NCAA tournament hopes in jeopardy. K.C. Rivers scored 15 and Trevor Booker had 14 with 10 rebounds for the Tigers (19-9, 5-9). Clemson has lost four in a row, seven of eight and nine of 11 since winning its first 17 games to become the last unbeaten team in Division I. Its only two victories since Jan. 9 were against Florida State and Boston College. The Tigers had a 30-25 lead at the break, but BC scored 11 of the first 14 points of the second half to take a 36-33 lead with 14:25 left. The Eagles made it 44-38 on Dudley's 3-pointer with 12:15 to play before Clemson scored the next eight points to go ahead. But Dudley tied it with a putback, then converted the three-point play to start and 11-0 run that put BC ahead for good. Tyrelle Blair blocked six shots for BC, which shot 31 percent from the floor in the first half. Clemson made just 27 percent of its shots in the second. Clemson had been 17-1 when leading at the half.
